senses.de: A request to a higher court to review a lower court's decision
senses.ex: David's lawyer filed an appeal against the verdict.

Tips.title: Court Hierarchy
Tips.description: Use 'appeal' when discussing seeking judgment from a higher legal authority.
Tips.example: After losing the case, the defendant chose to appeal.

Tips.title: Legal Process
Tips.description: 'Appeal' is a formal term, specifically used in legal contexts.
Tips.example: The appeal process can be lengthy and complex.

senses.de: A plea or request for help or support
senses.ex: They made a public appeal for information about the crime.

Tips.title: Pleading Tone
Tips.description: Use 'appeal' for earnest requests reflecting urgency or seriousness.
Tips.example: The family's appeal for a missing relative was heart-wrenching.

Tips.title: Context of Need
Tips.description: 'Appeal' often implies that assistance or support is desperately needed.
Tips.example: The flood victims made an appeal for clean water.

senses.ex: The appeal of city life is the vibrant culture and multitude of leisure activities.

Tips.title: Personal Subjectivity
Tips.description: 'Appeal' suggests subjective attraction; what appeals to one might not to another.
Tips.example: The appeal of snowy landscapes varies from person to person.

Tips.title: Widespread Interest
Tips.description: When many are attracted to or interested in something, it 'has appeal'.
Tips.example: The new phone model has wide appeal due to its features.

senses.ex: The charity is appealing for donations to help those affected by the flood.

Tips.title: Assistance and Support
Tips.description: 'Appeal' as a verb often conveys an urgent request for help.
Tips.example: Local charities appeal to the public after natural disasters.

senses.de: Apply to a higher court for a reversal of a decision
senses.ex: They decided to appeal the judgement.

Tips.title: Legal Re-evaluation
Tips.description: Use 'appeal' to indicate a formal request to reconsider a legal decision.
Tips.example: Unsatisfied with the outcome, they appealed the ruling.

senses.ex: The idea of a holiday appeals to everyone in the family.

Tips.title: General Attractiveness
Tips.description: Use 'appeal' to express general interest or attractiveness in non-legal contexts.
Tips.example: Working from home appeals to many because of its flexibility.

Tips.title: Emotional Connection
Tips.description: Something that 'appeals' often resonates on an emotional level.
Tips.example: The story's theme of hope appeals to a wide audience.

Allure.wordDefinition:
Allure and appeal are similar in that they both describe a quality that something or someone has that makes it attractive or desirable.

Allure typically refers to a sense of magic or mystery that makes something especially captivating or fascinating. For example, a mysterious person might have an allure about them that draws others in.

However, allure tends to be more evocative of a sense of magic or intrigue, while appeal focuses more on tangible elements that create attraction.

Attractive.wordDefinition:
Attractive means having qualities or features that are pleasing or appealing to the senses or the mind. It describes something that is physically or emotionally appealing to someone.

For example, a person may be attractive because they have a beautiful smile or an appealing personality.

Appeal is more related to the effect something has on others, while attractive is more related to the qualities or features of something that make it appealing to others.

Charm.wordDefinition:
Charm refers to the ability of something or someone to captivate or enchant others, often through a certain personality, wit or charisma.

Charms can be seen as more personal and intimate, as opposed to the more general appeal.

Both words can be applied to a wide range of contexts, but generally appeal is more objective, while charm is more subjective.

For example, a movie might have broad appeal to many different types of viewers, but a particular actor might be said to have a charming personality that only resonates with certain people.

Appeal is about something being attractive or interesting to a broad audience, while charm is about a certain personal quality that creates a deeper connection with a smaller group of people.

Entice.wordDefinition:
Entice means to attract or persuade someone mainly through excitement or pleasure.

For example, “The smell of freshly baked cookies entices me to come into the kitchen.”

To summarize, appeal is used when something has logical or good qualities that make it attractive, while entice is used when something has exciting or pleasurable features that make it attractive.

Entreaty.wordDefinition:
Both appeal and entreaty refer to a request or plea for someone to do something.

However, appeal is usually used when asking a higher authority to review a decision or judgment, while entreaty is used when making a sincere and emotional request to someone for help or assistance.

For example, a person might appeal a court decision, but make an entreaty for forgiveness from a loved one.

Fascination.wordDefinition:
Fascination is used when something captivates or intrigues someone, often because it is strange or unusual.

Appeal describes something that is attractive and positive, while fascination describes something that is captivating and intriguing, regardless of whether it is positive or negative.

Magnetism.wordDefinition:
Magnetism on the other hand refers to a kind of attraction that is almost irresistible.

For example, a charismatic speaker might have a magnetism that makes people want to listen to what they have to say.

Appeal is more about the specific qualities of something that make it attractive, while magnetism is more about the deeper, intangible quality of attraction that something or someone has.

Petition.wordDefinition:
A petition is a request or a formal written document asking an authority figure or government to take a specific action or change a policy.

It is often used by individuals or groups to raise awareness about an issue and to gather support for a cause. For example, a petition could be created to request that a school administration implement a new policy or to demand changes to a local law.

Appeal is used in legal situations to challenge a decision, while petition is used to ask for action or change from an authority figure or government.

Plea.wordDefinition:
Plea refers to a request made by a defendant in a court of law, asking for mercy or leniency in sentencing. For example, a defendant may plead guilty to a crime and ask for a lesser punishment.

So, while appeal is more about changing a decision, plea is about requesting leniency or making a case for a more favorable sentencing.

Request.wordDefinition:
Appeal refers to making a serious and urgent request for something, often in an emotional manner, and may involve a formal legal process.

Request refers to asking for something politely or formally and often implies that the person asking has less power or authority than the person they are asking.

It can be used in a variety of situations, from asking someone for a favor to requesting information from a company or government agency.

The main difference is that an appeal is a more serious and urgent request made to a higher authority, while a request is a more general term that can apply to any polite or formal asking for something.

Supplication.wordDefinition:
Supplication refers to a humble and earnest request or prayer, often addressed to a divine or higher power. For example, a person may make a supplication to a deity for help or guidance.

Both appeal and supplication involve making requests or pleas, but they differ in their context and focus. Appeals are often made in a formal or legal setting, whereas supplications are more personal and spiritual in nature.

Temptation.wordDefinition:
Temptation refers to the urge to do something that is considered wrong or forbidden. It's usually used in the context of something negative, and often involves a moral dilemma.

For example, eating a slice of cake when on a diet would be considered a temptation, as it goes against one's desire to be healthy.

Appeal refers to the attractiveness of something, while temptation refers to the urge to do something that is considered wrong or forbidden.

Appeal is usually positive, while temptation is usually negative.

quotes.Text: I'm appealing to people who want something different, but the world, on the whole, doesn't really embrace different things. Not on the whole.
quotes.Title: British Musician
quotes.Name: FKA twigs

quotes.Text: Coming-of-age stories are always appealing, especially as a young man who's still trying to figure out this complicated world.
quotes.Name: Finn Cole

quotes.Text: I think the one group I am trying to appeal to is the world. That would be big enough.
quotes.Title: British Musician
quotes.Name: Estelle

quotes.Text: I appeal to my fellow scientists to remember their responsibility to humanity.
quotes.Title: Polish Physicist
quotes.Name: Joseph Rotblat

quotes.Text: The life of a true, traditional stand-up is really unappealing for women.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Ali Wong

quotes.Text: Watching familiar characters take unexpected turns is very appealing.
quotes.Title: American Producer
quotes.Name: Marc Platt

quotes.Text: There are things about the single lifestyle that are very appealing.
quotes.Title: American Cartoonist
quotes.Name: Seth MacFarlane

quotes.Text: The power of Playboy is its appeal around the world.
quotes.Title: American Businesswoman
quotes.Name: Christie Hefner

quotes.Text: Truth knows no color; it appeals to intelligence.
quotes.Title: American Theologian
quotes.Name: James Hal Cone
